Explanation: Formed by raising intonation in speech or adding a question mark in writing; word order remains the same as in statements.
Formed using interrogative words such as chi (who), che cosa/cosa (what), dove (where), quando (when), perché (why), come (how).
Some questions require prepositions before the interrogative, e.g., Con chi? (With whom?), Di che cosa? (About what?).
Inversion of subject and verb is rare in Italian; instead, subject pronouns may follow the verb for emphasis or clarity.
Words used to join phrases or sentences: e (and), ma (but), o (or), anche (also), perché (because).
Words like perché (because), quindi (therefore), allora (so) are used to express reasons and results.
Words and phrases to indicate order: prima (first), poi (then), dopo (after), infine (finally).
